wordpressPost.title: Sustainability-focused employee engagement can improve customer experience
wordpressPost.content:
The vast majority of global business leaders’some 72 percent according to Forrester Research, Inc.‘say that improving the customer experience is a top business priority, “making it one of the most important drivers of business success today.

Customer experience lives and dies with your employees

Despite being a priority, a recent study from Gallup’a thought leader in employee engagement’reported on trends showing that employees primarily responsible for the customer experience are being neglected. The study found that employee engagement levels for service employees have decreased over the last few years, while employee engagement levels for all other positions within a company have increased. This is a problem for those businesses invested in customer experience, because employee engagement and customer experience are tightly intertwined, and service employee neglect negatively impacts the customer.

In a recent interview on VentureBeat, Michael Moritz, chairman of Sequoia Capital stated, For most consumers, customer service is a horrific experience most of the time. All too often, unengaged employees are talking to unhappy customers. Zeynep Ton, author of The Good Jobs Strategy, calls this low cost, bad jobs approach that many companies take, succeeding at the expense of employees and at the expense of customers.

If improving the customer experience is a top business priority, the first step is to engage those employees responsible for making customers happy.

Engaged employees will go the distance

An article published earlier this year by Bain and Company, states that a B2B company’s most effective weapon consists of highly engaged employees who go the extra distance to deliver. Engaged employees are more likely to feel ownership to their work, increased motivation to solve customer problems, and a deeper connection to the customer experience they help create.

Of course, better customer experience isn’t just in the hands of service employees. In a different report, Bain and Company not only states that engaged employees provide better experiences for customers, but claims they also approach the job with energy’which enhances productivity’and come up with creative product, process and service improvements, all of which, serve the customer.

Measurable returns from employee engagement

And yet, engaging employees doesn’t just improve your customer experience. Aon’s ‘2013 Trends in Global Employee Engagement‘ report found that companies with 72% or higher engagement, attain 50% higher TSR [Total Shareholder Return] than the average organization. A 2010 report by Hay Group, a global management consulting firm, found that companies with highly engaged workers grow revenues two and a half times as much as those with low engagement levels. Put simply: Happy employees = Happy customers = Happy shareholders.

A step forward with sustainability

If you’re looking for an effective employee engagement strategy to improve customer experience, sustainability-focused programs could be your answer:

One of our customers, Caesars Entertainment, recently commissioned Harvard Business School to examine this linkage between employee engagement and customer experience. The results showed a strong linkage between high employee participation in their sustainability-focused employee engagement program, Code Rewards, and increased customer loyalty and satisfaction.

So if you want to improve your customer experience, focus on your employees. They will take care of the customers, and so much more. And if you need a place to start, a sustainability-focused program could be the best way to jump-start your engagement efforts.
